Article Title: Supreme Court stays order for Akola SIT with Hindu, Muslim officers
Article Text:
.

NEW DELHI: A three-judge bench of the Supreme Court on Tuesday stayed a two-judge bench's order directing Maharashtra to set up a Special Investigation Team (SIT), comprising police officers belonging to Hindu and Muslim communities, to probe two crimes related to the 2023 communal riots in Akola.Appearing for Maharashtra, solicitor general Tushar Mehta told a bench of CJI B R Gavai and Justices K Vinod Chandran and N V Anjaria that police personnel lose their religious identity once they don the uniform, and a directive to set up the SIT based on the faith of members would violate the principles of secularism that governs the functioning of forces.He said the state is duty bound to conduct a free and fair probe and constitute an SIT - as was directed on Sept 11 by the bench of Justices Sanjay Kumar and S C Sharma. On Nov 7, the same bench gave a split verdict on Maharashtra govt's petition seeking review of the part of the order where govt had been directed to choose police personnel for SIT based on their personal faith.Mehta said the CJI, being from Maharashtra, must be aware that the state has many competent police officers. "Without taking instructions from the state, I can say that the state would not object if the CJI chooses the police officers who would form the SIT for a probe into the two incidents," he said.Staying the part of the two-judge bench's order that was related to the composition of the SIT, CJI-headed bench issued notice to the petitioner at whose request SC had earlier passed the order. "We cannot pass any order without hearing the complainant," the bench said.In deciding the review petition, Justice Sharma had said, "In the considered opinion of this court, as review and recall has been sought of the judgment to the limited extent that 'it directs or mandates the composition of the SIT on the basis of religious identity' requires consideration and, therefore, let notice be issued to the respondents, returnable within two weeks."But Justice Kumar dismissed the review petition and said the directive for including police officers belonging to Hindu and Muslim communities in the SIT was issued because of laxity on part of the police to register FIRs and investigate the two crimes relating to the communal riots.Given the split verdict, the matter was posted before a three-judge bench.
Article Summary: A three-judge bench of the Supreme Court on Tuesday stayed a two-Judge bench's order directing Maharashtra to set up a Special Investigation Team (SIT) The SIT was to probe two crimes related to the 2023 communal riots in Akola. On Nov 7, the same bench gave a split verdict on Maharashtra govt's petition seeking review of the order.

Article Title: Jawed Habib, son get interim relief in fraud case
Article Text:
Jawed Habib

PRAYAGRAJ: Allahabad HC on Monday granted interim protection from arrest to celebrity hairstylist Jawed Habib and his son Anosh Habib in an alleged multi-crore investment fraud, and directed authorities against taking any coercive action against them until police conclude the investigation and file a chargesheet.A bench of Justices Siddhartha Varma and Achal Sachdeva disposed of petitions filed by the father-son duo challenging 32 FIRs lodged by different "investors" against them in UP's Sambhal . They had also sought a restraint on their arrest as an interim measure.
Article Summary: Allahabad HC grants interim protection from arrest to celebrity hairstylist Jawed Habib and his son Anosh Habib in an alleged multi-crore investment fraud. Justices Siddhartha Varma and Achal Sachdeva disposed of petitions filed by the father-son duo.

Article Title: Kolkata court seeks Centre response to contempt pleain Sunali case
Article Text:
.

KOLKATA: The Calcutta HC, while hearing a contempt plea on Tuesday against the Centre for failing to comply with its order to bring back six migrant workers deported to Bangladesh, including Sunali Khatun and her family, directed Union govt to submit a statement by Nov 28, report Srishti Lakhotia & Subrata Chattoraj.The counsel representing the deported workers' families told a division bench comprising Justices Tapabrata Chakraborty and Reetobroto Kumar Mitra that the Centre had filed a special leave petition (SLP) in the Supreme Court challenging HC order. However, the SLP had defects in its filing, the counsel argued.Govt filed the SLP against HC ruling that quashed Delhi FRRO's deportation order on Oct 22, two days before the deadline set by HC ended.The bench on Sept 26 had directed govt to bring back Sunali, her husband and child, as well as Sweety Bibi and her two sons from Bangladesh, where they are lodged in a jail.
Article Summary: Calcutta HC directed Union govt to submit a statement by Nov 28. Centre had filed a special leave petition (SLP) in the Supreme Court challenging HC order. However, the SLP had defects in its filing, the counsel argued.

Article Title: Supreme Court to get Malur recount result, not Election Commission
Article Text:
S

KOLAR: Recounting of votes polled on EVMs in Malur assembly constituency of Karnataka during the 2023 assembly elections continued till close to midnight in Kolar on Tuesday. This is the first time in the country that votes cast through EVMs in an assembly election are being re-tabulated, with the outcome set to be placed before Supreme Court rather than Election Commission Karnataka HC had ordered the recount after BJP candidate K S Manjunath Gowda challenged the 248-vote victory of Congress MLA K Y Nanje Gowda.
Article Summary: This is the first time in the country that votes cast through EVMs in an assembly election are being re-tabulated. The outcome set to be placed before Supreme Court rather than Election Commission. Karnataka HC had ordered the recount after BJP candidate challenged the 248-vote victory of Congress MLA K Y Nanje Gowda.

Article Title: Bypolls for 8 seats see high to moderate turnout
Article Text:
.

NEW DELHI: High to moderate voting was recorded in the bypolls to eight assembly constituencies spread across six states and the Union territory of Jammu and Kashmir on Tuesday, with Dampa in Mizoram and Anta in Rajasthan clocking a percentage of over 80.Besides Dampa and Anta, the other seats that went to polls are Budgam and Nagrota in Jammu and Kashmir, Ghatshila in Jharkhand, Jubilee Hills in Telangana, Nuapada in Odisha and Tarn Taran in Punjab.While Dampa saw a turnout of 82.3%, it was 80.3% in Anta, 79.4% in Nuapada, 75.1% in Nagrota, 74.6% in Ghatshila, 61% in Punja's Tarn Taran, 50% in Budgam, and 48.5% in Jubilee Hills at the end of polling. Votes will be counted on Nov 14.Voting passed off peacefully in all the seats. In Odisha, two poll officials were suspended for failing to maintain voting secrecy.The Anta bypoll, which was necessitated after BJP MLA Kanwar Lal Meena was disqualified following his conviction in a criminal case, saw 15 candidates in the fray, with the contest primarily between BJP's Morpal Suman and Congress candidate and former minister Pramod Jain Bhaya. The bypoll in Dampa was necessitated following the death of incumbent MNF legislator Lalrintluanga Sailo in July.In Budgam, polling began amid chilly conditions as the valley witnessed sub-zero night temperatures at most places. The poll percentage of 50 was slightly lesser than the last year's assembly polls of 52.3%.
Article Summary: High to moderate voting recorded in the bypolls to eight assembly constituencies. Dampa in Mizoram and Anta in Rajasthan clocked a percentage of over 80. Other seats that went to polls are Budgam and Nagrota in Jammu and Kashmir, Ghatshila in Jharkhand, Jubilee Hills in Telangana and Nuapada in Odisha.
